CITY OF FREDERICK
FREDERICK LINGANORE WATER TREATMENT PLANT
RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM RE-SUBMITTAL
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY INTRODUCTION 68.155                                                                        
The City of Frederick Utilities Department operates the Linganore Water Treatment Plant at 6436 Plant Rd, Frederick, Frederick County, Maryland.  This plant is one of four water plants operated by the City.  The City also operates one wastewater treatment plant.  The Linganore water plant as well as the Monocacy water plant and the wastewater plant have quantities of regulated hazardous chemicals above the EPA threshold.  The City has a unified Risk Management Program which applies to each plant.  Only the Linganore Water Treatment Plant operations and policies are presented in this Plan.
1.1.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES     (A)
The City of Frederick Water Treatment Plant accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures and management practices.  The plant prevention program complies with all applicable procedures of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) 40 CFR-68 Prevention Program under the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990.
1.2.    MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS (A) (1)
The City of Frederick has a management system in place which is lead by the City's Mayor, who delegates implementation and on-going use of the RMP elements to the Public Works Department Director.  The Director delegates the RMP program to the Utilities Acting Deputy Director who has responsibility for water treatment plant operations and RMP Program implementation.  This program, along with other City-wide and plant-specific policies, eliminates and /or reduces the likelihood of a hazardous chemical release at the plant.  An organizational chart defining the lines of authority and responsible staff is included in the plants RMP Process Safety Information.
1.3.    PRE

VENTION PROGRAM LEVEL 3 (A) (2)
The City of Frederick maintains policies, procedures and systems as part of their prevention program.  These are applied to each treatment plant and specifically the Linganore Water Treatment Plant.  The program addresses each of the EPA Prevention Program Level 3-listed 12 elements, and other RMP elements needed to implement the program, and the like elements in place in the plants OSHA PSM program which the City has been in compliance with.  These program documents are maintained City of FrederickA?s water plant Superintendent and the CityA?s Risk Coordinator.
2.    STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE 
The City of Frederick Water Treatment Plant employs six (6) full-time employees engaged in water treatment plant and field operations.  Chlorine is used as part of the treatment process.
2.1.    SITE DESCRIPTION (B) (1)    
The site is owned and operated by The City of Frederick and managed by its Public Works Department.  The site is located at 6436 Plant Rd, Frederick, Frederick County, Maryland.  The site is located in a forested area, boarded by Linganore River on the west.
The Plant includes a separate chlorine storage and feed room and adjacent chlorine control room which also houses the injection feed distribution system.  The chlorinated water feeds various injector points in the plant.  Chlorinated water beyond the chlorine control room is outside in the boundaries of this process. 
The boundaries of the chlorine system subject to the RMP regulation include the Bulk Chlorine Storage Feed Control and Chlorination Control Room, associated vent makeup, exhaust systems and chlorine injection units in the chlorine control room as well as utility support system.  These are detailed in the Process and Instrument Drawings (P&ID) which are part of the plant Process Safety Information (PSI).  All drawings are maintained in the plants RMP Process Safety Information.
2.2.    REGULATED SUBSTANCE (B) (2)
Chlorine is the only regulated substance

on site which exceeds the EPA 40 CFR-68 rule threshold quantity of 2500 pounds.  The City of Frederick chlorine process was installed as part of the process of purifying water for public consumption.  It operates under permit from the State of Maryland Department of Environmental Protection (MD DEP).  The chlorine is received, stored and distributed to several process control systems. 
Chlorine is an EPA and OSHA-listed toxic chemical.  It is an irritant and corrosive.  Chlorine is a halogen with the formula Cl2.  Chlorine is an oxidizing agent that is non-flammable.  It has a 1 ppm OSHA ceiling 15 minute permissible exposure limit (PEL) and a NFPA health rating of 4, severe; with immediate and delayed health hazards.  Chlorine is not a carcinogen.
The maximum quantity stored on site is eight (8) each one ton containers.  This equals 16,000 pounds.  The maximum threshold quantity stored on site is eight (8) each one ton containers.  This equals 16,000 pounds.  The immediate dangerous health (IDLH) level is 10 ppm and a lethal concentration (LC-5O) of 250 ppm.
.
3.    HAZARD ASSESSMENT
A hazard assessment was performed to determine the effects a release would have on the public and environment surrounding the plant.  For chlorine, the distance to the endpoint concentration which the gas would travel was determined.  In addition, an estimate of the population that could be affected by a release of chlorine was determined, and sensitive receptors such as hospitals, schools, and nursing homes were identified.  The hazard assessment considers two release scenarios: a "worst case" and an "alternative case".  The City maintains a five-year accident requirement for the WTP chlorine system (see Section 5 below: Five Year Accident History).
Two offsite consequence analyses were conducted which include two chlorine release scenarios.  The first is a "worst case release".  The second is a more probable "alternative release scenario".  The first scenario is defined by EPA, which st

ates that "the operator shall assume that the maximum quantity in the largest vessel is released as a gas over 10 minutes" due to an unspecified failure.  The alternative scenario is defined more "more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario".
Atmospheric dispersion modeling was performed to determine the distance traveled by the chlorine released before its concentration decreases to the "toxic endpoint."  The EPA specified endpoint for chlorine is 0.0087 mg/l which equals 3 ppm.  The 3 ppm endpoint is the Emergency Response Planning Guideline Level 2 (ERPG-2).  This is defined by the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) as the A?maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individualA?s ability to take protective action.A?  The residential population within a circle with a radius corresponding to the toxic endpoint distance was defined, A?to estimate the population potentially affected.A?
3.1.    WORST CASE   (C) (1)
Atmospheric dispersion modeling for the worst case scenario was performed using the EPA assumptions and EPAA?s RMP Comp Program.  Data and assumptions used were: 
A?    A gas liquefied under pressure, 
A?    a one ton container releasing 2,000 lbs
A?    Quantity released 200 lb/minute
A?    The duration is 10 minutes   
A?    No mitigation measure
A?    Topography: urban surroundings (many structures in area)
A?    Wind speed 1.5 meters/second
A?    Stability Class F
A?    Air temperature 77 degrees F.  
Results demonstrate a distance to the toxic endpoint of *** miles containing *** square miles of area assuming an urban topography without an enclosure.  The residential population that could potentially be affected by the release is *** individuals based on the U. S. Census 2000 demographic data.  There are residences and other receptors included in the release area (commercial

facilities and parks) (Note: see PSI for details).
3.2.    ALTERNATIVE CASE   (C) (2)
The alternative release scenario involves the failure of the regulator of the pressure system or the pipes/valves connected to one of the 150 pound cylinders.  This failure was defined during the recent Process Hazards Analysis.  This failure is equal to creating a 0.004 square inch hole in the yoke, drip tube, a pipe, or even the container itself.  Modeling using the EPA/RMP Comp and EPAA?s guidance demonstrated the rate of chlorine release is 14.8 lb. /minutes for a period of 30 minutes releasing a total of 440 pounds of chlorine.  The toxic endpoint distances were determined using the following assumptions:
A?    A gas liquefied under pressure, 
A?    14.8 lb/min release
A?    30 minute duration
A?    quantity release 440 lbs
?    no mitigation measure 
?    urban surroundings
?    wind speed 3 meters/second
?    stability class D
?    Air temperature 77A? F
The toxic endpoint is *** miles and is located in the process safety information.  The residential population that would be impacted by this release is *** and is recorded in the process safety information.  Receptors in this area were identified as residences, industrial areas, etc.
4.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM (D)
The City of Frederick accidental release prevention program is based on OSHA's PSM program and EPA's RMP Level 3 prevention program.  The PSM program has been effectively used for many years.  It and the RMP programs are part of the plants operating culture.  There are two parts to the program.  The first is the general overall Water and Sewer Division wide program and the Water Treatment Plant site program.  The second is the chlorine-specific actions within the site program.  Both are coordinated with the Frederick County Fire/Rescue Department (including the Haz Mat Team) and the Regional LEPC.
4.1.    GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM   (D) (1)
Plant-wide, many elements of the prevention program are used for all oper

ations.  An overview of the generally written programs is listed below:
The City of Frederick has detailed process safety information on each of its operations. 
The document maintenance system is integral to the management of change for all operations on site control.  This system is computer based.
Training is the backbone of employee knowledge, job operations and is ongoing in each area.  Employee training in operations and maintenance emphasizes awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of all chemicals used. 
Maintenance and preventive maintenance are used for all operations making mechanical integrity a part of each piece of equipment.  The maintenance program uses a computer based work order system for scheduled mechanical integrity as well as for unplanned repairs and maintenance. 
Incident investigations of accidents and near-miss incidents ensure we learn from each event as well as correct the causes of the incident.  If there is a chlorine release, significant injury, or property damage; an investigating team is formed and reviews the incident within 48 hours of the determination of the occurrence. 
Employees participate in all aspects of the plant as listed below under emergency response.  Employees are also safety committee members Process Hazards Review members and developers of the various P&PA?s.
Safe work practices are used throughout the facility including:  1) Hot Work Permits, 2) Lock Out Tag Out Permits, 3) Vessel Entry Permits, 4) Site Security, and 5) Breaking Into Chemical Lines. 
Contractors must meet The City of FrederickA?s high safety and technical standards as part of selection and ongoing evaluations.  In addition, City of Frederick demands training of contractors to our standards. 
4.2.    CHLORINE SPECIFIC RESPONSE PROGRAM (D) (2)
4.2.1.    Chlorine-Specific Operating Safety Information
Chemical-specific prevention features of the plant include: the policies and procedures listed above and those of the chlorine specific program.  Thes

e include:
4.2.2.    Specific procedures for the management of the chlorine process 
There is a specific procedure for the Completion of a Management of Change for all modified and/or new processes.  This is followed by Completion of a Pre-startup Safety Review prior to startup of the modified chlorine system.   
There are specific emergency response procedures for chlorine releases as outlined below under both operating procedures for small releases and in the emergency response procedures for large releases.  See the Emergency Response Program manual. 
There is specific training in the properties, hazards, handling requirements, and leak repair for chlorine. 
Finally, the details of both facility and equipment design are key in the operations manual of the chlorine system.
4.2.3.    Facility Design
The chlorine storage is located in a room of the chemical building.  The plant and support equipment of the chlorine storage building and adjacent control room meet and exceed design codes standards and good engineering practices.  The storage area and control building room are equipped with forced ventilation system.  There is a chlorine area monitor inside the storage building rooms.  If chlorine is detected, the monitor alarms.  The chlorine control room also has a chlorine monitor.  Both monitors alarms and a flashing red light illuminates in their local area as well as in the water plant control room.  The alarm system is tied into the security system which alerts management.  Finally, the chlorine alarm starts the chlorine room ventilation system. 
4.2.4.    Equipment Design
There are two types of chlorine pipe systems, high pressure and low (vacuum) pressure.  The high pressure chlorine piping system is very short as it only includes the valve on the ton containers and yoke assembly and vacuum pressure regulator.  These parts are made of anhydrous (elemental) chlorine compatible materials; steel, copper or chlorine compatible non-metallic compound (not corroded by chlorin

e) rated to 500 psig.  The maximum pressure of the chlorine in the high pressure system is only 150 psig giving a 3 to 1 safety factor.  There is one each ton containers on line, and one each full one on standby.  There is an automatic switchover within the vacuum pressure regulator.  One container is in service and the other is on standby. 
The low pressure system operates under a vacuum pressure of 13 inches of mercury.  A pressure relief valve vents if the pressure in the line reaches above 12 inches of water pressure.  All the pipe, tubes, and equipment are also chlorine compatible.  The system is designed to 150 psig or complete vacuum giving it a large safety factor over the typical vacuum or positive pressure in it.  A chlorine monitor detects the presence of chlorine in both the ton storage area and in the chlorine control room. 
5.    FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY (E)
The plant has been chlorine reportable and release free since 1992 to the present, 18 years.    
6.    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM (F)
Emergency response procedures are contained in both the Plant Emergency Response Policy and City Emergency Response Plan which is coordinated with the Frederick County Contingency Plan (Emergency Response Plan).  The plan includes an emergency response "decision tree" and a notification plan.  The Plant also has site specific emergency actions for small and large (reportable) release defined in the plant's operating procedures and Emergency Response Plan.  Emergency response drills and drill evacuations are conducted annually by the operating department.  Emergency operation and response procedures are also reviewed annually.
The emergency response program (contingency plan) is coordinated (reviewed by) with the water plant Safety Committee, the City Fire and Police Departments.  The Water Plant and Fire Department coordinates with Local Frederick County Emergency Response Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Frederick County HazMat Team.  All are located in Frederick Count

y, Maryland.  Copies of the program are given to key local agencies including: fire, medical, rescue, management, and police departments.  Besides the specific emergency response program, key elements of the prevention programs are incorporated in the operating culture of the City water plant.
The Emergency Response or Contingency Plan procedures detail the actions and responses to chlorine spills (releases).  The plan includes training of all chlorine-area operators and maintenance staff.  The primary response team includes the Frederick County Fire and Rescue, and Frederick County Haz Mat Teams.  All of these respond to severe chlorine leak situations.  Actions include response to: catastrophic, severe, and moderate leaks.  A Chlorine "B" Leak Repair Kit is maintained at the chlorine storage area to aid in stopping leaks.  Public notification is facilitated through the City Police and County Sheriff's Office, which has an automated emergency dialing message system for public notification.
7.    PERSONNEL (F) (1)
Personnel are the key resource of the City of FrederickA?s prevention program.  City employees make up the operators and emergency first response teams.  The City of Frederick fosters a high level of involvement in every aspect of the chlorine system operations including participation in:
A?    PSM/RMP safety teams, 
A?    Development of the operation procedures, 
A?    Hazard evaluations 
A?    Process Hazards Analysis and  
A?    On-going training of the operators and other involved staff.
8.    CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY (G)
Changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were identified in the internal safety HazOp, tour, and audit of the RMP program to meet requirements of the Risk Management Prevention Program. These recommended actions have now been evaluated and implemented as required.  Another major change was made to improve safety in 2005.  The high pressure chlorine pipe system was replaced with a container mounted vacuum regulator.  An Audit was conducted to revie

w the RMP program in 1999 and April 2005 and 2010.  The key safety action items were completed.  See the Update Section 6 of this report.  The City of Frederick continually reviews implemented operating procedures for potential safety improvements for all of its operations.  Currently, the City of Frederick management team and process safety team are reviewing potential upgrades to the existing design of the chlorine operations to make the system even safer to prevent a release and minimize consequences in the event of a release of chlorine.
The City of Frederick Water Treatment Plants compiled the EPA required Vulnerability Assessment.  Recommendations from the VA Report improve site security and safety over all including that of the chlorine system.
